instruction: My parents want me to move back to the village to take care of them, but my life and work are in the city. I feel guilty for staying here.
context: User is a 28-year-old woman from a rural area near Mhondoro, now living in Harare where she works as a shop manager.
response: This is a tough situation. Many parents hope their children will return home, especially as they age, but it’s also important that you build your own life. Your love and care don’t have to mean physically moving back. You could show support by visiting regularly, sending what you can, or arranging for another family member to assist them. Sometimes, explaining your situation gently to your parents with respect can help them see that staying in the city also strengthens the family in the long run.

instruction: My wife says I don’t spend enough time with her because I’m always helping my siblings. I don’t want her to think I don’t love her.
context: User is a 33-year-old Shona man in Kadoma. He often gives time and money to his siblings, leaving his wife feeling neglected.
response: It sounds like your heart is in the right place—you want to support your family, but also value your marriage. In our culture, siblings rely heavily on each other, yet your wife is also your closest partner. It may help to set aside dedicated time for her, even small things like a weekly outing or evening talk. Reassuring her with words and actions can help her feel secure while you still support your siblings within limits you both agree on.

instruction: My brother doesn’t respect me because I didn’t go to university like he did. He treats me like I’m less important.
context: User is a 27-year-old man in Rusape who works as a mechanic while his brother studied at university.
response: That must feel hurtful. Education is valued highly, but it doesn’t define someone’s worth. Your skills as a mechanic are equally important to the community. Sometimes siblings compete, but it might help to calmly express to your brother how his words affect you. You could also focus on building your confidence by taking pride in the work you do. Respect in families often grows when we stay steady in who we are, even if others don’t see it right away.

instruction: My in-laws want me to stop working so I can stay at home with the children, but I enjoy my job.
context: User is a 31-year-old woman in Victoria Falls, Ndebele, married with two children. She works in tourism.
response: I hear how torn you must feel. In some families, there’s still an expectation that mothers stay home, but times have changed and many women balance work and family. Your work brings value, not only to you but to your family’s future. It may help to sit with your husband and share how important your job is to you, so you face the in-laws together as a united voice. Respectful dialogue, showing that the children’s needs are met, might ease their concerns.

instruction: Ever since my father died, my uncles keep arguing over inheritance. I feel stuck in the middle.
context: User is a 25-year-old woman in Zvishavane, Shona, whose father recently passed away, leaving behind disputes over land and property.
response: I’m sorry you’re caught in this conflict—it can be very painful when family relationships are strained by inheritance. In Shona tradition, uncles often take a strong role, but that doesn’t mean you should carry the burden of their disagreements. It may help to ask a respected elder or community leader to mediate. Protecting your peace during this grieving period is also important—you have a right to step back when the arguments become too heavy.

instruction: My husband doesn’t want to live near my family, but I feel lonely away from them.
context: User is a 29-year-old woman in Masvingo. She recently moved to a new area with her husband and feels isolated.
response: Feeling lonely away from your family is natural, especially when you’re used to close support. Sometimes husbands prefer distance to avoid family tensions, but your need for connection is also valid. It may help to talk openly with him about finding balance—for example, regular visits or phone calls with your family, while also respecting his space. Building friendships in your new community could also reduce the loneliness while keeping ties with your family alive.

instruction: My parents want me to marry within our tribe, but I fell in love with someone from a different culture.
context: User is a 24-year-old woman in Harare. She is Shona, while her partner is Ndebele.
response: This is a very real challenge in many families, as cultural identity carries weight. It’s not unusual for parents to fear losing traditions when children marry outside the tribe. But love across cultures is possible with respect. Perhaps you could introduce your partner slowly, showing his respect for your family’s ways. Sometimes elders soften when they see genuine commitment and kindness. Your love deserves to be considered as much as tradition.

instruction: I feel like my siblings take advantage of me because I live abroad. They expect me to pay for everything back home.
context: User is a 35-year-old man living in the UK, with extended family in Zimbabwe depending on him financially.
response: Many in the diaspora feel this burden. Families often think life abroad means endless money, but the reality is different. Saying no doesn’t mean you don’t care. You might consider setting clear limits and explaining openly what you can manage. It may also help to involve a trusted elder who can explain to your siblings that you cannot carry everything alone. Protecting your financial stability is important for you and your future too.

instruction: My mother doesn’t approve of my girlfriend because she is older than me.
context: User is a 23-year-old man in Mutare dating a woman five years older than him.
response: It’s understandable that your mother has concerns—age differences can raise questions in many families. But what matters most is the strength of your relationship. You might try explaining to your mother what you appreciate about your girlfriend and how she supports you. Approaching the conversation respectfully, and perhaps asking a family elder to support you, may help your mother see that your choice is thoughtful and serious.

instruction: My parents want me to be a doctor, but I want to study art. I’m afraid they’ll see me as a failure.
context: User is an 18-year-old student in Harare, finishing A-levels. He wants to pursue fine arts.
response: It sounds scary to go against your parents’ expectations. In many families, careers like medicine are seen as security, especially in Zimbabwe’s economy. But your passion for art is also important for your happiness and growth. Could you share with them how art could still bring opportunities, maybe even showing examples of successful artists? Sometimes parents soften when they see a plan and seriousness behind your dream. You deserve a future that feels true to you.

instruction: My uncle keeps reminding me that I am not married yet, even at family gatherings. It embarrasses me.
context: User is a 33-year-old woman in Bindura, unmarried and facing pressure at gatherings.
response: That must be very uncomfortable. In our culture, uncles sometimes believe they are guiding, but their words can sting. You could prepare a polite but firm response, such as ‘I am focusing on building my life right now.’ Sometimes sharing your achievements can shift the conversation. If it continues, it might help to confide in a trusted *vatete* or elder who can gently ask him to stop. Your life is not less valuable because of marriage status.

instruction: My wife and my mother don’t get along. I feel stuck in the middle of their arguments.
context: User is a 34-year-old married man in Chiredzi. His wife and mother have frequent conflicts.
response: Being caught between your mother and wife can be exhausting. Both women are important in your life, but it helps to make your marriage the partnership where decisions are made together. You could talk to your mother respectfully, affirming your love for her while asking for space to build your marriage. At the same time, reassure your wife that she is your priority. Balancing respect for your mother with loyalty to your wife takes patience but is possible.

instruction: My father doesn’t listen when I tell him I want to move out. He says it’s disrespectful.
context: User is a 22-year-old man in Bulawayo, still living at home though he desires independence.
response: It’s natural to want independence at your age, but some parents see moving out before marriage as rejection. Perhaps you could explain to your father that you are grateful for his support but want to learn responsibility by standing on your own. Framing it as growth rather than rejection may help. You could also ask a respected elder to support your explanation so your father sees it as a step of maturity, not disrespect.

instruction: My in-laws always want to make decisions about our marriage, and my husband lets them. I feel like I have no voice.
context: User is a 28-year-old woman in Masvingo, newly married and living close to her husband’s parents.
response: It must feel frustrating to feel unheard. In many families, in-laws play a strong role, but your marriage also needs space for your voices. You might share your feelings gently with your husband, emphasizing teamwork rather than blame. Encouraging him to stand with you as a couple could make it easier to set respectful boundaries with his parents. Building a balance between honoring them and protecting your partnership will help your marriage grow.

instruction: My sister is always borrowing money from me, but she never pays back. When I say no, she gets angry.
context: User is a 30-year-old man in Gokwe, with siblings depending on him financially.
response: It can be hard to say no to a sibling, especially in Zimbabwean families where sharing is expected. But constantly giving without return can drain you. It may help to set a clear rule—if she hasn’t repaid one loan, you can’t give another. You could explain gently that you care about her but also need to be responsible with your money. Sometimes firm boundaries, expressed with love, protect relationships from resentment.

instruction: I feel like my parents only value me when I send them money. Otherwise, they don’t really check on me.
context: User is a 27-year-old woman in South Africa, sending remittances to her parents in Zimbabwe.
response: That must feel painful—to be seen more as support than as a daughter. Sometimes in difficult economic times, families get caught up in survival and forget the emotional side. It may help to tell your parents directly that while you understand their needs, you also long for their love and conversation beyond money. Sharing your feelings calmly could open their eyes. Remember, your worth to them is not just in what you provide financially.

instruction: My cousin wants me to be the go-between for his marriage negotiations, but I don’t feel ready for that responsibility.
context: User is a 29-year-old Shona man in Murehwa. His cousin is asking him to play the role of go-between in paying *roora*.
response: It’s understandable to feel nervous. The role of go-between is respected but carries a lot of responsibility. You don’t have to say yes if you’re uncomfortable. You could explain to your cousin that you appreciate the trust but prefer that an older or more experienced uncle take the role. This way, you maintain respect while also protecting yourself from stress. Courage also means knowing when to step back.

instruction: My aunties keep saying I am cursed because I haven’t married yet. It makes me question myself.
context: User is a 32-year-old woman in Chinhoyi, single and facing stigma from relatives.
response: I hear how painful those words must be. Unfortunately, in some families, people explain life circumstances with ideas of curses, but this is not a reflection of your value. You are not cursed—you are a whole person whether married or not. You might choose to ignore such comments, or respond calmly that you are focusing on your journey. Talking to supportive friends, church members, or a trusted *vatete* could also help you feel less alone.

instruction: My grandfather wants me to take over the family farm, but I want to start a business in town.
context: User is a 24-year-old man in rural Mashonaland Central, facing pressure to inherit farming land.
response: That is a difficult choice. In many families, land is seen as legacy, so your grandfather may be trying to secure the family’s future. But your dreams of business are also valid. Perhaps you could suggest finding a way to honor both—helping ensure the farm is cared for, maybe by another family member, while you pursue your business. Respectfully explaining your vision may help your grandfather see that you are still committed to the family’s wellbeing, just in a different way.

instruction: My wife complains that I’m too close to my mother, but she has always been the one I lean on.
context: User is a 35-year-old man in Harare, married for five years, with a strong attachment to his mother.

Loving and respecting your mother is important, but your wife also needs to feel that she is your closest partner. You might reassure her by involving her more in your decisions and setting aside time just for her. You can still honor your mother while showing your wife that she comes first in your marriage.

instruction: My father-in-law always undermines me in front of my wife. I feel humiliated.
context: User is a 29-year-old man in Marondera, married, and living close to his wife’s family.

You might gently ask your wife to support you in those moments so you face it together. Over time, showing maturity and calmness can win your father-in-law’s respect. Remember, your dignity matters too.

instruction: My younger brother refuses to take responsibility at home. Everything falls on me.

response: It’s hard to carry so much on your own. Sometimes younger siblings avoid responsibility when they know someone else will pick up the slack. You could try having an open talk with him, making clear what you need help with. Setting specific tasks rather than general expectations might make it harder for him to avoid. You deserve support, and asking other relatives to step in may also lighten the load.

Many Zimbabwean families worry about how stepchildren will fit in, but love and commitment can build strong families. If your relationship is serious, you might help your parents see the positive qualities she brings. Respectfully explaining that you value her and her child may open their eyes with time.

instruction: My mother always compares me to my cousins who have better jobs. It makes me feel small.
context: User is a 25-year-old woman in Chitungwiza, working part-time and living with her parents.

You might gently tell your mother how her words affect you. Focusing on your own progress, even small steps, can help you rebuild your confidence. You are not defined by how you measure against cousins.

instruction: My uncle keeps pressuring me to send money for family ceremonies, but I’m struggling myself.
context: User is a 32-year-old man in Johannesburg, often called on to contribute to family events back in Zimbabwe.

You might offer what you can, even if it’s your time or advice, instead of money. Respectful honesty is better than overstretching yourself. Protecting your own stability ensures you’ll be able to support in the future too.

instruction: My stepmother treats me differently from her own children. I feel left out.
context: User is a 19-year-old student in Masvingo, living with father and stepmother.

You could try sharing your feelings with your father, asking for his support in making sure you’re treated fairly. Building relationships outside the home—friends, teachers, mentors—can also remind you of your worth.

instruction: My wife and I keep fighting about how to raise our children. She says I’m too strict.
context: User is a 36-year-old man in Karoi, married with two children.
response: Parenting differences are common, especially when one parent is stricter than the other. It may help to sit down and talk about what values you both want your children to learn, then agree on a middle ground. Children thrive when parents show unity, even if compromises are needed. Listening to each other without judgment can make discipline more consistent and loving.

instruction: My father doesn’t believe in therapy. He says problems should only be solved by prayer.
context: User is a 22-year-old woman in Bulawayo, studying at university and interested in mental health support.
response: Many elders rely strongly on faith, and prayer is indeed a powerful source of comfort. At the same time, therapy can complement prayer by giving you tools to cope. You don’t need to choose one over the other. If your father isn’t ready to accept therapy, you could quietly seek support for yourself while respecting his beliefs. Both faith and counseling can walk side by side.

instruction: I want to start a small business, but my parents insist I must first get a government job.
context: User is a 26-year-old man in Kwekwe, recently graduated from university.
response: It’s natural for your parents to want security for you, as government jobs were once the safest option. But the economy today is different, and small businesses can also provide stability. Perhaps you could show them your plan, including how you’ll manage risks. Parents often become more supportive when they see that you’ve thought carefully. You can honor their advice while still following your dream.

instruction: My mother criticizes everything I do, even how I cook or clean. I feel like nothing is good enough.
context: User is a 20-year-old woman in Mutare, living with her parents.
response: That must be exhausting. Some parents show love through correction, but constant criticism can hurt deeply. It may help to remind yourself that her words don’t define your worth. If possible, you could calmly tell her how it makes you feel, or choose to focus on small things she appreciates. Building self-confidence outside the home—in friendships or hobbies—can also protect your sense of self.

instruction: My sister-in-law always tries to control how I run my household. I don’t know how to stop her interference.
context: User is a 31-year-old woman in Chinhoyi, married and living close to her husband’s family.
response: It can be very draining when relatives interfere in your marriage. In Shona and Ndebele culture, sisters-in-law often have strong opinions, but you and your husband are the ones building the home. It may help to talk with your husband about setting boundaries together, so he can support you. Responding to her with respect but firmness can also show her that you value her advice, but decisions rest with you as a couple.

instruction: My father keeps reminding me that he paid a lot for my education, so I must obey his wishes in everything.
context: User is a 24-year-old man in Harare, recently graduated and looking for work.
response: It’s true that your father sacrificed a lot for your education, and it’s good to acknowledge that. But his investment doesn’t mean you can’t have your own path. Respectfully expressing gratitude while also sharing your goals might ease his expectations. Sometimes involving another trusted elder to mediate can help parents hear your voice without feeling disrespected.

instruction: My mother says I must have a child soon, but I don’t feel ready for motherhood.
context: User is a 26-year-old woman in Hwange, recently married, facing pressure from her family.
response: In many families, having children quickly after marriage is expected, but readiness matters too. It’s okay to take your time. You might gently explain to your mother that you want to prepare emotionally and financially before starting a family. Having your husband’s support in this conversation could also help. Your journey to motherhood should be guided by your readiness, not just pressure.

instruction: My cousins say I’ve become too proud since I moved to the city. I just want a better life.
context: User is a 28-year-old man originally from rural Matabeleland, now living in Bulawayo.
response: It must hurt to feel misunderstood. Sometimes when someone improves their life, relatives interpret it as pride. You might reassure your cousins by staying connected—visiting, calling, or showing small acts of humility. At the same time, remember that your growth is not something to be ashamed of. You can succeed and still honor your roots.

instruction: My aunt raised me, but now that I’m working, she expects me to provide everything for her household. I feel used.
context: User is a 30-year-old woman in Harare, working as a nurse.
response: It’s true that your aunt cared for you, and it’s natural to want to give back. But providing for an entire household alone is too heavy for one person.
